docs.abstract: The deputy attorney general, Rod J. Rosenstein, who has been overseeing the investigation while Matthew G. Whitaker spoke with ethics lawyers, will continue to manage the inquiry day to day.
docs.snippet: The deputy attorney general, Rod J. Rosenstein, who has been overseeing the investigation while Matthew G. Whitaker spoke with ethics lawyers, will continue to manage the inquiry day to day.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Matthew G. Whitaker, the acting attorney general, has decided not to recuse himself from the Russia investigation, despite being advised otherwise by a career ethics official, according to a Justice Department letter sent to Senate leaders. Mr. Whitaker will now have final say over any major developments made in that inquiry.

headline.main: Acting Attorney General Whitaker Won’t Recuse Himself From Russia Inquiry

docs.abstract: Jim Mattis, the defense secretary, released the letter shortly after President Trump announced Mr. Mattis’s departure on Twitter.
docs.snippet: Jim Mattis, the defense secretary, released the letter shortly after President Trump announced Mr. Mattis’s departure on Twitter.
docs.lead_paragraph: President Trump on Thursday tweeted that Defense Secretary Jim Mattis would be leaving the Pentagon in February. The news comes a day after the president announced troop withdrawals in Syria.

headline.main: Read Jim Mattis’s Letter to Trump: Full Text
headline.print_headline: Full Text Of Letter  To Trump From Mattis

docs.abstract: Questions about whether the president is a Russian agent made clear that the government shutdown may be just the initial skirmish in an all-out battle between him and Congress.
docs.snippet: Questions about whether the president is a Russian agent made clear that the government shutdown may be just the initial skirmish in an all-out battle between him and Congress.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — So it has come to this: The president of the United States was asked over the weekend whether he is a Russian agent. And he refused to directly answer.

headline.main: Trump Confronts the Prospect of a ‘Nonstop Political War’ for Survival

docs.abstract: But the nominee, William P. Barr, also suggested that he was aware that he could not stop the president from ordering him to end the investigation.
docs.snippet: But the nominee, William P. Barr, also suggested that he was aware that he could not stop the president from ordering him to end the investigation.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — William P. Barr, President Trump’s nominee for attorney general, promised on Monday that he would allow the special counsel to continue his investigation, seeking to allay Democrats’ fears that he might shut down the inquiry.

headline.main: Attorney General Nominee Promises to Allow Mueller to Finish His Work
headline.print_headline: Attorney General Nominee Would Let Mueller Finish

docs.abstract: American steel manufacturers got an initial boost from Mr. Trump’s tariffs but have since seen their share prices decline and steel prices fall.
docs.snippet: American steel manufacturers got an initial boost from Mr. Trump’s tariffs but have since seen their share prices decline and steel prices fall.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has latched on to the idea of using steel to build his wall along the southern border, praising himself for fulfilling two campaign promises at once: keeping out illegal immigrants and resuscitating a struggling industry.

headline.main: U.S. Steel Companies Face Downturn Despite Trump Claims of Revival

docs.abstract: Senators pressed President Trump’s choice to run the Justice Department on his expansive views of executive power and how he’ll protect the special counsel.
docs.snippet: Senators pressed President Trump’s choice to run the Justice Department on his expansive views of executive power and how he’ll protect the special counsel.
docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. Barr used his opening remarks to the committee to clarify that he has no intention of firing Mr. Mueller before his work is done and to indicate that he would provide “as much transparency as I can consistent with the law” around the investigation’s results. The rule of law, he insisted, should be above and outside of the politics that divide the nation.

headline.main: William Barr Hearing: Senators Press Barr on Criminal Justice Overhaul

docs.abstract: As the White House tries to get the government functioning, President Trump invited Democrats to the White House, hoping to find cracks. They rejected his lunch date.
docs.snippet: As the White House tries to get the government functioning, President Trump invited Democrats to the White House, hoping to find cracks. They rejected his lunch date.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration said Tuesday that it would summon tens of thousands of federal employees back to work without pay to get the government running amid a partial shutdown well into its third week, as the White House and increasingly agitated lawmakers on Capitol Hill cast about for a way to end the stalemate.

headline.main: Trump Summons Thousands Back to Work Without Pay as Shutdown Drags On
headline.print_headline: Plan to Summon Workers Back Without Pay as the Deadlock Drags On

byline.original: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

docs.abstract: President Trump on Thursday sent a letter to Speaker Nancy of Pelosi of California saying, “I am sure you would agree that postponing this public relations event is totally appropriate.”
docs.snippet: President Trump on Thursday sent a letter to Speaker Nancy of Pelosi of California saying, “I am sure you would agree that postponing this public relations event is totally appropriate.”
docs.lead_paragraph: President Trump on Thursday responded to Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California one day after Ms. Pelosi wrote him suggesting a delay to the annual State of the Union address because of the government shutdown.

headline.main: Read Trump’s Letter to Pelosi on Her Foreign Trip

docs.abstract: The vote to enforce sanctions on an oligarch’s companies was an overwhelming show of disapproval of Trump administration policy, but it was mostly symbolic because a similar Senate measure had failed.
docs.snippet: The vote to enforce sanctions on an oligarch’s companies was an overwhelming show of disapproval of Trump administration policy, but it was mostly symbolic because a similar Senate measure had failed.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In what was most likely a largely symbolic vote, 136 House Republicans joined with Democrats on Thursday in an overwhelming show of disapproval of the Trump administration’s policy toward three Kremlin-aligned companies.

headline.main: 136 House Republicans Join Democrats in Vote Against Russia Sanctions Relief

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump regularly expresses pique over scathing kiss-and-tell books written by former aides and advisers. But he had no beef with “Let Me Finish” by Chris Christie, the former New Jersey governor and his onetime transition director.

headline.main: What Do You Learn About Trump in an 85-Minute Interview?
